title: Building macOS installer fails
body:
pup throws the following error:
```I Step 'mac.create-dmg': starting.
I dmgbuild err: Traceback (most recent call last):
I dmgbuild err:   File "/Users/carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/venv-pup/bin/dmgbuild", line 5, in <module>
I dmgbuild err:     from dmgbuild.__main__ import main
I dmgbuild err:   File "/Users/carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/venv-pup/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dmgbuild/__init__.py", line 1, in <module>
I dmgbuild err:     from .core import build_dmg
I dmgbuild err:   File "/Users/carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/venv-pup/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dmgbuild/core.py", line 42, in <module>
I dmgbuild err:     from mac_alias import *
I dmgbuild err: AttributeError: module 'mac_alias' has no attribute 'kBookmarkVolumePathkBookmarkVolumeURL'
E [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/Users/carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/build/pup/Mu Editor.dmgbuild/Mu Editor 1.2.0.dmg'
I Step 'mac.create-dmg': completed.
```
This comes from the `mac_alias` package, which is installed as a depedency of `dmgbuild`, which is a depedency of `pup`.

The issue is already identified, and a PR raised, but it hasn't been merged and released yet:
- https://github.com/dmgbuild/mac_alias/issues/21
- https://github.com/dmgbuild/mac_alias/pull/20

Possible workarounds right now:
a. Update pup to pin `mac_alias==2.2.0`
b. Install `mac_alias==2.2.0` in the pup virtual env, before installing pup

Option a) might take a little while, as Tiago is likely busy at the moment and might not have the bandwidth to do a release soon (@tmontes tagging you for visibility, but no need to look into this right now).

I'll prepare a PR for option b), which we can remove when the next version of `mac_alias` is released.

title: AppImage Debian Bullseye / Lubuntu 22.04 w/ X11  "Segmentation fault"
body:
### What were you trying to do?

Use Mu-Editor

### What steps did you take to trigger the issue?

I followed the steps from https://codewith.mu/en/howto/1.1/install_linux

### What did you expect to happen?

mu-editor would run

### What actually happened?

I got a segmentation falt

### Operating System Version

Debian Bullseye 11.4 and Lubuntu 22.04

### Mu Version

1.1.1

### Other Info

```
carles@pinux:~$ ./Mu_Editor-1.1.1-x86_64.AppImage
No settings file found at /home/carles/.local/share/mu/venv.json; skipping
Segmentation fault
carles@pinux:~$ QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland ./Mu_Editor-1.1.1-x86_64.AppImage
No settings file found at /home/carles/.local/share/mu/venv.json; skipping
Failed to create wl_display (No such file or directory)
qt.qpa.plugin: Could not load the Qt platform plugin "wayland" in "" even though it was found.
This application failed to start because no Qt platform plugin could be initialized. Reinstalling the application may fix this problem.

Available platform plugins are: eglfs, linuxfb, minimal, minimalegl, offscreen, vnc, wayland-egl, wayland, wayland-xcomposite-egl, wayland-xcomposite-glx, webgl, xcb.

Aborted
carles@pinux:~$ 
```

For the Debian: `apt install mu-editor` worked. For the LUbuntu I then had to apply the patch from https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/2228

I'm happy to follow up any debugging for the Debian Bullseye. I will not have (easy) access to the LUbuntu after tomorrow's (will be with the kids that will use it).

Both the Debian and LUbuntu installations use X11. Debian with lxde and LUbuntu with lxqt.

As said: no work around needed for me, reporting only so the projects know. Thanks very much for writing mu-editor! :-)

### Editor Log

_No response_

title: Replace dead links and fix typos
ESP MicroPython device incorrectly identfied as "Arduino Clone"

labels.name: devices
labels.description: Requests for new device addition or support for existing devices

body:
As the CP210x USB VID and PID have been registed in the Snek Mode.

The large majority of the ESP boards (excluding the newer versions with built-in USB) have this USB-to-UART chip, so if we don't correct this they won't be detected as MicroPython boards.

title: Runtime error: wrapped C/C++ object of type xxx has been deleted
body:
## Issue

Looks like we might have some PyQt5 widgets/objects garbage collected, and then some function schedule in some kind of event tries to access them, raising a runtime error.

This has been been resolved in one ocassion for a QLabel in PR https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/pull/1694 for issue https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1474 and release in [1.1.0-beta.6](https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/releases/tag/1.1.0-beta.6).

In this case the majority of cases we see now are:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\interface\panes.py", line 760, in on_ls_fail
    self.disable()
  File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\interface\panes.py", line 699, in disable
    self.microbit_fs.setDisabled(True)
RuntimeError: wrapped C/C++ object of type MicroPythonDeviceFileList has been deleted
```


## User workaround

Nothing at the moment, this error happens occasionally, so Mu can be launched again.

title: Error creating user venv: `no such option: --symlinks`
body:
## Problem

In some cases when Mu tries to create a virtual environment it throws the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/mu/app.py", line 160, in run
    raise ex
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/mu/app.py", line 147, in run
    venv.ensure_and_create(self.display_text)
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 603, in ensure_and_create
    self.create()
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 793, in create
    self.create_venv()
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 829, in create_venv
    raise VirtualEnvironmentCreateError(
mu.virtual_environment.VirtualEnvironmentCreateError: Unable to create a virtual environment using /Users/microbit-carlos/workspace/carlos/mu/.venv/bin/python at /Users/microbit-carlos/Library/Application Support/mu/mu_venv-38-20220603-193434
STDERR: Usage: virtualenv.py [OPTIONS] DEST_DIR
virtualenv.py: error: no such option: --symlinks
```

This is caused by the addition of the `--symlinks` flag to the venv creation as part of PR https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/pull/1863/:
https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/a180f8627b4f3cad2d23cd428dfab8b8b7a0d93c/mu/virtual_environment.py#L810-L818

We currently support virtualenv version `>=16.7.6` and the `--symlinks` flag was added in v20.0.0 (it's not in the changelog, had to manual check):
https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/a180f8627b4f3cad2d23cd428dfab8b8b7a0d93c/setup.py#L67

## User workarounds

This should not affect Mu installations from the Windows/macOS installers or the linux AppImage, should only manifest when Mu was installed using pip **AND not** in a virtual environment

In that case you can update the `virtualenv` version to version 20.x or higher.


However, the main recommendation is to install Mu using a virtual environment. Alternatively I personally recommend using [pipx](https://pypa.github.io/pipx/), which installs Python applications in their own venv automatically.

title: `pip install mu-editor` with incompatible Python versions fetches old incompatible releases
body:
## Problem

Currently Mu is only compatible with Python version 3.5 to 3.8 (both included).
This is marked as such with the `python_requires` property:
https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/0596a5251ef4615818fe59837837a82f1430bdd4/setup.py#L125

- If a user with an incompatible Python version, like 3.9 or 3.10, runs `pip install mu-editor` pip will know it cannot install v1.1.x ✅
- However pip will go through all the releases until it finds a compatible Mu release.
- Since we only added the `python_requires` property in the v1.1 betas, pip believes v1.0.3 (and any earlier release) is compatible and will try to install it. ❌

Of course, any version of Mu pip find will not be compatible, and it fail at the point it tries to install some of the  dependencies, as they were version locked years ago and don't have wheels for the newer Python releases.

## User workarounds

For uses installing Mu with pip, you have to use Python 3.5 to 3.8.

If you don't have those versions of Python on your system (for example, you are using Debian Bullseye, which comes with Python 3.9), there are two options:
- Find out how to install Python 3.5 to 3.8 in your system (Python 3.8 preferred), and then install Mu using a virtual environment created with that version of Python
- Use one of the Mu Installers or AppImage from https://codewith.mu/en/download

For Ubuntu 22.04, the "Install Mu via PyPI and pipx" workaround listed in this issue shows the steps to get Python 3.8 and install Mu with pipx: https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/2228

title: Clamp click version to workaround issue with black & other CI fixes
body:
Click is a black dependency and the latest releases (>8.0.4) have broken older black releases (<22.3.0).
https://github.com/psf/black/issues/2964

Ideally we should update black to the latest version, but right now we might  want to keep compatibility with older black releases.
Once we update all dependencies, including black, we can remove click.

title: Fix typo in the Russian locale
body:
On my linux system, trying to rebuild the locales results in a fatal error for the Russian one due to unescaped quote. More specifically:

msgfmt mu.po -o mu.mo
mu.po:262:55: syntax error
mu.po:263: end-of-line within string
msgfmt: found 2 fatal errors

The PR fixes the typo and allows the locale to be built.

title: Mocking super() in tests breaks with setuptools 60.6+
body:
### What were you trying to do?

Run mu tests with latest setuptools installed

### What steps did you take to trigger the issue?

We are rebuilding an older version of mu in Fedora with setuptools 60.9 as we are rebuilding everything. I suppose the newer version of mu has the same problem as the test has never changed.

I don't have an easy reproducer yet. I assume running the tests with setuptools 60.9 should be enough.

The CI here appears to run with an older setuptools version.

I can submit a PR that should try to update it and we can see if it triggers the same failure: https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/pull/2092

### What did you expect to happen?

The tests should pass

### What actually happened?

The tests fail with:

```
=================================== FAILURES ===================================
__________________________ test_ButtonBar_add_action ___________________________

    def test_ButtonBar_add_action():
        """
        Check the appropriately referenced QAction is created by a call to
        addAction.
        """
        bb = mu.interface.main.ButtonBar(None)
        with mock.patch('builtins.super') as mock_s:
>           bb.addAction('save', 'Save', 'save stuff')

tests/interface/test_main.py:119: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
mu/interface/main.py:121: in addAction
    action = QAction(load_icon(name), display_name, self,
mu/resources/__init__.py:37: in load_icon
    return QIcon(path(name))
mu/resources/__init__.py:32: in path
    return resource_filename(__name__, resource_dir + name)
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:1141: in resource_filename
    return get_provider(package_or_requirement).get_resource_filename(
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:360: in get_provider
    return _find_adapter(_provider_factories, loader)(module)
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:1591: in __init__
    self._setup_prefix()
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <pkg_resources.DefaultProvider object at 0x7f572f61fcd0>

    def _setup_prefix(self):
        # Assume that metadata may be nested inside a "basket"
        # of multiple eggs and use module_path instead of .archive.
>       eggs = filter(_is_egg_path, _parents(self.module_path))
E       AttributeError: 'DefaultProvider' object has no attribute 'module_path'

/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:1596: AttributeError
```

This is because you mock super and pkg_resources now use it as well:

https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a7c6d64f76091d1cfd8297ba813fe4e901d00ce4

I suppose mocking super is dangerous :biohazard: 

### Operating System Version

Fedora Linux 37

### Mu Version

1.0.3 but the same tests still exist

### Other Info

_No response_

### Editor Log

_No response_

title: Issue collection: First pip install fails with exit code 101
body:
Linking here several Crash Reports with the same issue. When it's about to install the first wheel (`backcall` in this case) it encounters an error.

Things they all have in common:
- Fails on the first wheel installation (`backcall`)
- Exit error is 101
- **All user names have a space in it**
    - So this is directly related to https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1372

With beta.5 and newer the 101 error code is returned at the time it tries to install wheels. In earlier versions there are some other crash reports with the same exit code, more info in: https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1926#issuecomment-994687363

title: " compatible" string is no good for translation
body:
### What were you trying to do?

Translate Mu

### What steps did you take to trigger the issue?

I bootstrapped translation by running `make translate_begin LANG=pt_BR` and then started translating with my preferred PO editor.

After some strings, I hit `" compatible"` string. Its source location is in

https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/12d80470add3f790a0a38cc559106a618773f3b3/mu/logic.py#L576

It is used in `def name`, so I believe it returns "SOME_BOARD compatible".

### What did you expect to happen?

Be able to properly translate it.

### What actually happened?

The string `" compatible"` is impossible to be translated. In Portuguese, when something is FOOBAR-compatible, I have to translate reordering to something like "compatible with FOOBAR" (but in Portuguese, obviously). With the current partial string I can't do this correctly,



### Operating System Version

Ubuntu 20.04 LTS WSL2

### Mu Version

N/A

### Other Info

I suggest to have it rephrased with placeholders. E.g. `" {boardname} compatible"` 

### Editor Log

_No response_

title: Virtual env runtime fix for running as Linux AppImage.
body:
FACT:

* While exploring Linux AppImage packaging [in this `pup` PR](https://github.com/mu-editor/pup/pull/183) I found a serious limitation.
* Each time Mu runs (as an AppImage thingie) it is mounted under a different mount point.
* This invalidates existing virtual envs because their interpreter -- a symlink to the `python` executable in Mu's installation -- no longer exists (it does, but each time under a different path).

THIS PR:

* Detects that we're runing as an AppImage.
* Re-symlinks the existing virtual env (if any) interpreter to the currently valid system interpreter.

PS: Isn't packaging fun? :)

title: Mu's packaged Python links/uses packages from other Python environments
body:
Summary in this link contains the current state of this issue after the initial fix was shipped:
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1831#issuecomment-1001262368

----

Some crash-reports/exceptions are caused by Mu calling missing attributes or methods from the API of Python packages that are packed with Mu.

In these cases when the user runs `sys.path` with Mu's Python we see an entry for a different Python environment, for example:

```
'C:\\Users\\xxxxx\\AppData\\Roaming\\Python\\Python38\\site-packages'
```

Then looking at the output of `pip list --verbose` we can see that it picks up packages from that environment, for example:

```
Package        Version    Location                                                                   Installer
-------------- ---------- -------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------
mu-editor      1.1.0b5    c:\users\xxxxx\appdata\local\programs\mu editor\python\lib\site-packages
virtualenv     20.0.21    c:\users\xxxxx\appdata\roaming\python\python38\site-packages               pip
```

This can manifest in errors like:

```
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified: 'C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\python\mu\mu_venv-38-20210705-181446' -> 'C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\python\mu\mu_venv-38-20210705-181446.FAILED'
2021-07-05 18:14:54,271 - root:173(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\app.py", line 161, in run
raise ex
File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\app.py", line 148, in run
venv.ensure_and_create(self.display_text)
File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\virtual_environment.py", line 603, in ensure_and_create
self.create()
File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\virtual_environment.py", line 767, in create
self.create_venv()
File "C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\lib\site-packages\mu\virtual_environment.py", line 798, in create_venv
raise VirtualEnvironmentCreateError(
mu.virtual_environment.VirtualEnvironmentCreateError: Unable to create a virtual environment using C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Programs\Mu Editor\Python\pythonw.exe at C:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\python\mu\mu_venv-38-20210705-181446
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'virtualenv.seed.embed.via_app_data'
```

Or for PyQt5:
```
ImportError: DLL load failed while importing Qsci: the specified procedure could not be found.
```


Crash reports with this issue (growing list, there might be more):
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1602#issuecomment-913540799
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1612#issuecomment-905713548
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/51
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/52
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1867
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1875
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1933
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/53

Possible crash reports related to this (need more info):
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/54
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1542
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/55
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/56
- https://github.com/mu-editor/crash-reports/issues/57
- https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1928

title: Dark Mode should support f"{x}:{y}"
body:
### What were you trying to do?

Use an f-string while in dark mode.

### What steps did you take to trigger the issue?

```python
x=20
y=30
print(f"{x}:{y}")
```

### What did you expect to happen?

f-strings should look like other strings

### What actually happened?

The f-string is purple on white. The variables (x,y) are gray on black.

### Operating System Version

Windows 10

### Mu Version

1.1.0-beta-5

### Other Info

_No response_

### Editor Log

_No response_

title: Every time I open Mu Editor in my Raspberry Pi the window gets higher
body:
# Bug Report What were you trying to do? --------------------------- Open the editor What steps did you take to trigger the issue? --------------------------------------------- Just installed via pip What did you expect to happen? ------------------------------ I expected to get the window always at the same size and position on the escreen What actually happened? ----------------------- Every time I open the editor the window opens at a higher position in the screen Why is this difference problematic? (it might not be a bug!) ---------------------------------------------------------- Well, sometimes I just can't reach the top of the window to reposition it and so that I can't use the app. Technical Info -------------- * Mu version: Mu 1.1.0.beta.4 * Operating system version: Raspberry Pi OS (kernel version: 5.10) Other Info ---------- Editor Log ----------

title: Mu 1.1.0-beta-4 wont run at all
body:
I was previously using Mu 1.0.3 and ran into some glitches with a teensy 4.1 so I uninstalled it and tried installing the latest version following all the instructions and after it was installed I couldn't open it. When I launched for about 3 seconds I had a blue spinning loading thing and then it goes away and nothing comes on screen. I tried on another computer and had the same problem. Does anyone know what is wrong?

Im using:
Windows 10 home, 20H2, and the other computer I tested on was windows 10 as well though hasnt been update in a few months, I used the windows 64 bit installer.

I have tried:
restarting my computer multiple times, uninstalling it and reinstalling it multiplytimes, disabling Malwarebytes, updating to the latest windows 10, running it using administrator, I also tried 1.1.0-beta.3 and 1.1.0-beta.2 and a few other versions (only 1.0.2 and 1.0.3 worked though I didn't try all of them), I looked for it in task manager and didn't see it running.

I checked Windows: %LOCALAPPDATA%\python\mu\Logs for logs but there were no logs.

thank you for your help

title: venv pip install step does not install all wheels
body:
## Issue description
We've had a series of Crash reports where it looks like `pip install ...` step for wheels finishes successfully, but then the `pip list` only shows a partial list of packages.

These problems are usually manifested with the `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pgzero'` (or a different module), as it might have installed some of the wheels, but not reached `pgzero`.

## Example log
For example in https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1591 we find:

  Attempting uninstall: setuptools
    Found existing installation: setuptools 54.1.2
    Uninstalling setuptools-54.1.2:
      Successfully uninstalled setuptools-54.1.2
2021-05-24 14:48:26,649 - mu.virtual_environment:193(run) DEBUG: Process output: Package          Version
---------------- -------
backcall         0.2.0
colorama         0.4.4
decorator        5.0.7
ipython          7.22.0
ipython-genutils 0.2.0
jedi             0.18.0
jupyter-client   6.1.12
jupyter-core     4.7.1
MarkupSafe       1.1.1
parso            0.8.2
pickleshare      0.7.5
pip              21.1.2
prompt-toolkit   3.0.18
pycparser        2.20
Pygments         2.8.1
python-dateutil  2.8.1
pywin32          300
pyzmq            22.0.3
setuptools       56.0.0
six              1.15.0
tornado          6.1
traitlets        5.0.5
wcwidth          0.2.5
wheel            0.36.2
```
So it in this cased it failed at `cffi` as every wheels listed before it was installed correctly and none of the wheels installed after it are shown in the pip list.

## Theories

### Initial theory
Our assumption right now is that perhaps pip outputs an error in the stderr pipeline we are not capturing correctly in the log.
However, @tjguk has already looked into this and technically speaking it's all configured correctly. PR https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/pull/1530 reworks this slightly to see if a different method is capable to capture the missing output.

### Timeout theory

Added in https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1600#issuecomment-851633150:
I think maybe the problem we are seeing is a timeout of the pip install step from:
https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/de20993f82cf5b3e7c9d9efcfc282d83c6c427f7/mu/virtual_environment.py#L210-L217

If we separate each wheel into its own `pip install` it should resolve this possible problem and provide more granular info in the logs.

title: Cannot install pygame in Raspbian Stretch
body:
Unfortunately there are no Arm Stretch wheels for pygame v2.0.* in piwheels , which is the version required by the latest pgzero.

We could add a workaround in `mu.wheels` to install `pygame==2.0.0.dev14` (last available wheel, but it's a "pre-release") in this platform before it attempts to install `pgzero`, although ideally we should try to get the Arm wheels in piwheels as that might benefit everybody.

title: Mu Editor 1.1.0b4 does not add the file extension .py when saving a new file for the first time on Linux
body:
**Steps to recreate:**

1. Install the latest beta via pip in a virtual environment (Kubuntu 21.04 using a Python 3.8.10 virtual environment via pyenv).
2. Start the Mu Editor as normal.
3. Click on New to create a new tab.
4. Click on Save and in the resulting dialog box, enter a file name for the file, but do not add the .py extension and hit enter.

**Expected behaviour**

File saves with the .py extension added automatically.

**Actual behaviour**

File saves as a plain text file with no file extension.

This behaviour is different to that experienced on the Windows version which does add the file extension by default.

Thanks

title: Commenting (CTRL-K) deletes first character in the next line
body:
If you are reporting a bug, we would like to know:

* What you were trying to do,
From this code I tried to **comment the first `pixel.show()`**
`pixel[1] = (255, 255, 255)`
`pixel.show()`
`pixel[2] = (255, 255, 255)`
`pixel.show()`

* What steps you took to make this happen,
I placed the cursor at the beginning of the line **without highlighting** the command and I pressed CTRL-K

* What you expected to happen,
The line will be commented, like this:
`# pixel.show()`

* What actually happened,
The line is commented and highlighted, but the cursor placed into the next line and the **next line first character is deleted**:
`# pixel.show()`
`ixel[2] = (255, 255, 255)`

**IF the line is highlighted before CTRL-K, there is no any problem.**

* Why this difference is problematic (it may not be a bug!),
Because one character is deleted ...

* Technical details like the version of Mu you're using, your OS version and
  other aspects of the context in which Mu was running. 
MU version: 1.1.0.beta.2
OS: Windows 10 Pro, version 2004

Please remember to attach a **copy of the full log files for Mu**. 
The log is attached.
[log_Commenting (CTRL-K) deletes first character in the next line_Tizedes.txt](https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/files/6382285/log_Commenting.CTRL-K.deletes.first.character.in.the.next.line_Tizedes.txt)

title: Mu doesn't verify if all required (or unexpected) wheels are present in mu/wheels/
body:
It basically it (kind of) assumes that if any wheel is present, all required wheels are present.

https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/ad16f421b091f82b50124a176df429398482011f/mu/virtual_environment.py#L644-L649

Of course, if a wheels is missing, it will then fail the `ensure_key_modules()` step, so it will fail (correctly) at that point during the venv creation. But other than that it will not try to download the wheels at any stage. This might be good, if we don't want to have the Mu from installers trying to download wheels during the start up process. But it also means it misses a chance to recover if an internet connection is present.

This will initially mostly affect developer environments, as that is the easiest way to have differences between  `mu.wheels.__init__` and the present wheels, in this case we "just" need to remember to manually remove all the wheels from the `mu/wheels/` directory.

However, I think it could also be a problem for users pip upgrading Mu from PyPI. Does pip remove the old mu folder before installing the new? would the old wheels stay and cause this issue?


Perhaps we should verify in `install_baseline_packages` (the code snippet above) that all the wheels required in `mu.wheels.__init__` are present?

title: Fix TravisCI failures
body:
Now that the test flakiness is not as bad the TravisCI tests are not usually getting stuck and we can get the test results.
We should look into what the problem is and fix it.

title: Virtual Environment fails on Windows when user path contains a space
body:
(First reported via https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1367)

On the surface it appears that the check for the Python interpreter in `VirtualEnvironment.ensure` fails if the user's installation path contains a space -- typically because their username contains a space. Not verified yet, but the OP in that report confirmed that re-installing under a different username solved the problem.

title: Pip fail2
body: Force the `Pip` object to recreate its internal QProcess object on every run. This sidesteps the issue where it's first invoked as part of a worker thread during the Splash screen, causing every later invocation to run cross-thread

title: Help button links to home site error page
body:
Mu 1.0.2 on kubuntu 20.04 language nl
Help button >> ¡Lo siento! La página que buscas no existe. :-(

cause: site supports only 'en' and 'es'
fixed by editing /usr/share/mu-editor/mu/logic.py

added:
if language_code != 'en' and language_code != 'es':
            language_code = 'en'
above:
     url = 'https://codewith.mu/{}/help/{}'.format(language_code,major_version)

title: Settings tab in Python mode show other settings view
body: Originally reported in https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/pull/1278#issuecomment-775832810. Just tried this from master and seeing the same running from source code: It's hard to tell, but that's basically the micro:bit settings at the top left of the Python 3 settings tab bar: I can actually toggle the tick box from that tab area and it will apply the setting.

title: Issue with iPython REPL with Py3.8 Windows installer after using Py3.7 installer (venv pip install issue)
body: With the current master branch executable builds we have the Python 3 (3.7) REPL working correctly. title: Black is not bundled in the macOS app
body:
So when clicking the tidy button we get an error:

```
2021-02-10 21:12:46,049 - root:106(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/microbit-carlos/Downloads/Mu Editor.app/Contents/Resources/Python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mu/logic.py", line 1777, in tidy_code
    from black import format_str, FileMode, PY36_VERSIONS
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'black'
2021-02-10 21:12:46,053 - mu.settings:169(save) DEBUG: Saving to /Users/microbit-carlos/Library/Application Support/mu/session.json
2021-02-10 21:12:46,053 - mu.settings:169(save) DEBUG: Saving to /Users/microbit-carlos/Library/Application Support/mu/venv.json
2021-02-10 21:12:59,872 - root:172(run) INFO: 
```

Looking at the app bundle black is not present.

The  guards we have check the Python version instead of the package presence:
https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/7282e7d11faca3e64b91af54efb43a469cae6e1e/mu/logic.py#L1772-L1773

title: Tests flakiness and some test seems to be locking up in CI
body: The GitHub Actions jobs have been queuing since yesterday. The grey icons are test runs I had to cancel as they were stuck there for 4h+: - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802206901?check_suite_focus=true - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802207019?check_suite_focus=true - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802207054?check_suite_focus=true Other CI runs with a similar lock up: - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802309139?check_suite_focus=true - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802424340?check_suite_focus=true - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802424319?check_suite_focus=true - https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/runs/1802285428?check_suite_focus=true ## Update There was originally 2 issues, one to do with dependencies in Python 3.8 (already fixed) and another problem not yet identified where some runs get stuck: https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/1266#issuecomment-772083787

title: Python3(Jupyter) REPL "Kernel died, restarting"
body:
If you are reporting a bug, we would like to know:

* What you were trying to do,
* What steps you took to make this happen,
* What you expected to happen,
* What actually happened,
* Why this difference is problematic (it may not be a bug!),
* Technical details like the version of Mu you're using, your OS version and
  other aspects of the context in which Mu was running. 

Please remember to attach a **copy of the full log files for Mu**. You can get
the logs by clicking on the cog icon in the bottom right of the editor window.
Click on the logs and use CTRL-A to select all, then CTRL-C to copy and CTRL-V
to paste the contents into the issue.

Thank you for contributing to Mu! :-)

title: In Linux we may exit Mu with a KeyboardInterrupt if a QProcess fails to launch and we kill PID 0
Ability to remove essential packages (pip, setuptools, wheel)
body:
Hi all,

I just played around with the new master branch, which contains the new virtualenv based backend for managing installed packages. However, I found a way to remove pip, which makes Mu crash when you try to launch it again.

Here are the steps:
 - Install some third party package (e.g. packagedummy)
 - Close mu
 - Open mu again
 - Open the Third Party Packages, now pip, setuptools and wheel are added to the list:

![Screenshot 2021-01-07 at 11 30 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55204/103882258-d36b0c00-50db-11eb-909a-e8028c499b6a.png)

 - Remove pip from the list and click Ok:

![Screenshot 2021-01-07 at 11 31 35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55204/103882359-f695bb80-50db-11eb-9bd3-71b91846257e.png)

 - Try opening the admin dialog again

Mu crashes with the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/dpr964/Development/micropython/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 261, in installed
    next(iterlines)
StopIteration

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/dpr964/Development/micropython/mu/mu/logic.py", line 1394, in show_admin
    baseline_packages, user_packages = venv.installed_packages()
  File "/Users/dpr964/Development/micropython/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 519, in installed_packages
    for package, version in self.pip.installed():
  File "/Users/dpr964/Development/micropython/mu/mu/virtual_environment.py", line 267, in installed
    raise VirtualEnvironmentError("Unable to parse installed packages")
mu.virtual_environment.VirtualEnvironmentError: Unable to parse installed packages
```

title: mu-editor hangs on macOS Big Sur
body:
I have been using **mu-editor** successfully for a while under **Catolina** on my Mac. Today I upgraded the OS to **Big Sur**. Now the mu-editor does not open. When I launch it by clicking on the icon, the app just hangs. There are no error messages. 

I have to close the application through the "Force Quit Applications". In this window it shows that mu-editor is running but not responding.

I re-installed the editor with the latest version from the website, but this did not work either.

If you are reporting a bug, we would like to know:

* What you were trying to do: Launch the mu-editor
* What steps you took to make this happen: click on its icon
* What you expected to happen: Editor to open
* What actually happened: editor just hung - no error messages
* Why this difference is problematic (it may not be a bug!): The pp no longer works and I cannot run Python!!
* Technical details like the version of Mu you're using, your OS version and
  other aspects of the context in which Mu was running. 
macOS Big Sur V 11.0.1
mu_editor - the latest version (1.0.3? - hard to tell!)

Can't provide a log file as the editor does not open.

Please remember to attach a **copy of the full log files for Mu**. You can get
the logs by clicking on the cog icon in the bottom right of the editor window.
Click on the logs and use CTRL-A to select all, then CTRL-C to copy and CTRL-V
to paste the contents into the issue.

Thank you for contributing to Mu! :-)

title: UnicodeDecodeError when opening REPL in ESP MicroPython mode
body:
I just got this UnicodeDecodeError. I launched Mu with an M5StickC ESP32 device connected, tried to open the REPL and Mu crashed. We both need to figure out _why_ this happened, and also introduce some better error handling. Second invocation of Mu didn't crash, so I can't replicate it.

Here's the log:
```

title: MU Crashes when I click the REPL button
body:
Hey all,
Super super beginner. 
I downloaded MU, and then I tried to click the REPL button and the whole program just quit (crashed). 
Not sure what's required for you to help me but i have the problem report. 

PASTED BELOW (sorry it being super long!) 
Hope someone can help me out. 
(i downloaded python 3.8.2, then MU, then upon opening MU i clicked on REPL and it crashed)
Thanks!

title: microbit error
body:
i keep getting this issue for some reason, and eventually it will have finished flashing but nothing much happens. 
it will leave me with the message "there was a problem flashing the microbit, please do to disconnect until flashing has completed. please check the logs for more info"

# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan
# ECE 210 Lab 6
# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, Blue and mixed colors
# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness of each color
# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive
# Pin 4 to Pot
# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware

from microbit import *

display.off()

# Defining the state identiification
IDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)
# Initializing the states
state = IDLE

# Defining the idle state function
def handle_idle_state():
    global state
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = RED
        sleep(500)

# Defining the red state function
def handle_red_state():
    global state, angle_R
    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = GREEN
        sleep(500)

# Defining the green state function
def handle_green_state():
    global state, angle_G
    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = BLUE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the blue state function
def handle_blue_state():
    global state, angle_B
    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = WHITE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the white state function
def handle_white_state():
    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = IDLE
        sleep(500)

# Main state machine
while True:
    if state == IDLE:
        handle_idle_state()
    elif state == RED:
        handle_red_state()
    elif state == GREEN:
        handle_green_state()
    elif state == BLUE:
        handle_blue_state()
    elif state == WHITE:
        handle_white_state()

# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan
# ECE 210 Lab 6
# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, 
#Blue and mixed colors
# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness
# of each color
# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive
# Pin 4 to Pot
# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware

from microbit import *

display.off()

# Defining the state identiification
IDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)
# Initializing the states
state = IDLE

# Defining the idle state function
def handle_idle_state():
    global state
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = RED
        sleep(500)

# Defining the red state function
def handle_red_state():
    global state, angle_R
    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = GREEN
        sleep(500)

# Defining the green state function
def handle_green_state():
    global state, angle_G
    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = BLUE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the blue state function
def handle_blue_state():
    global state, angle_B
    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = WHITE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the white state function
def handle_white_state():
    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = IDLE
        sleep(500)

# Main state machine
while True:
    if state == IDLE:
        handle_idle_state()
    elif state == RED:
        handle_red_state()
    elif state == GREEN:
        handle_green_state()
    elif state == BLUE:
        handle_blue_state()
    elif state == WHITE:
        handle_white_state()

2020-03-22 17:47:45,489 - mu.logic:872(save_tab_to_file) DEBUG: # Write your code here :-)
# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan
# ECE 210 Lab 6
# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, 
#Blue and mixed colors
# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness
# of each color
# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive
# Pin 4 to Pot
# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware

from microbit import *

display.off()

# Defining the state identiification
IDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)
# Initializing the states
state = IDLE

# Defining the idle state function
def handle_idle_state():
    global state
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = RED
        sleep(500)

# Defining the red state function
def handle_red_state():
    global state, angle_R
    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = GREEN
        sleep(500)

# Defining the green state function
def handle_green_state():
    global state, angle_G
    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = BLUE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the blue state function
def handle_blue_state():
    global state, angle_B
    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = WHITE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the white state function
def handle_white_state():
    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = IDLE
        sleep(500)

# Main state machine
while True:
    if state == IDLE:
        handle_idle_state()
    elif state == RED:
        handle_red_state()
    elif state == GREEN:
        handle_green_state()
    elif state == BLUE:
        handle_blue_state()
    elif state == WHITE:
        handle_white_state()

# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, 
# Blue and mixed colors
# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness
# of each color
# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive
# Pin 4 to Pot
# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware

from microbit import *

display.off()

# Defining the state identiification
IDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)
# Initializing the states
state = IDLE

# Defining the idle state function
def handle_idle_state():
    global state
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = RED
        sleep(500)

# Defining the red state function
def handle_red_state():
    global state, angle_R
    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = GREEN
        sleep(500)

# Defining the green state function
def handle_green_state():
    global state, angle_G
    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = BLUE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the blue state function
def handle_blue_state():
    global state, angle_B
    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = WHITE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the white state function
def handle_white_state():
    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = IDLE
        sleep(500)

# Main state machine
while True:
    if state == IDLE:
        handle_idle_state()
    elif state == RED:
        handle_red_state()
    elif state == GREEN:
        handle_green_state()
    elif state == BLUE:
        handle_blue_state()
    elif state == WHITE:
        handle_white_state()

2020-03-22 17:52:33,480 - mu.modes.microbit:250(flash) DEBUG: b'# Write your code here :-)\n# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan\n# ECE 210 Lab 6\n# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, \n# Blue and mixed colors\n# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness\n# of each color\n# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive\n# Pin 4 to Pot\n# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware\n\nfrom microbit import *\n\ndisplay.off()\n\n# Defining the state identiification\nIDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)\n# Initializing the states\nstate = IDLE\n\n# Defining the idle state function\ndef handle_idle_state():\n    global state\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = RED\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the red state function\ndef handle_red_state():\n    global state, angle_R\n    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = GREEN\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the green state function\ndef handle_green_state():\n    global state, angle_G\n    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = BLUE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the blue state function\ndef handle_blue_state():\n    global state, angle_B\n    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = WHITE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the white state function\ndef handle_white_state():\n    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = IDLE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Main state machine\nwhile True:\n    if state == IDLE:\n        handle_idle_state()\n    elif state == RED:\n        handle_red_state()\n    elif state == GREEN:\n        handle_green_state()\n    elif state == BLUE:\n        handle_blue_state()\n    elif state == WHITE:\n        handle_white_state()\n\n\n\n'

2020-03-22 17:54:59,577 - mu.logic:872(save_tab_to_file) DEBUG: # Write your code here :-)
# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan
# ECE 210 Lab 6
# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, 
# Blue and mixed colors
# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness
# of each color
# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive
# Pin 4 to Pot
# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware

from microbit import *

display.off()

# Defining the state identiification
IDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)
# Initializing the states
state = IDLE

# Defining the idle state function
def handle_idle_state():
    global state
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = RED
        sleep(500)

# Defining the red state function
def handle_red_state():
    global state, angle_R
    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = GREEN
        sleep(500)

# Defining the green state function
def handle_green_state():
    global state, angle_G
    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin3.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = BLUE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the blue state function
def handle_blue_state():
    global state, angle_B
    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    pin1.write_analog(0)
    pin2.write_analog(0)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = WHITE
        sleep(500)

# Defining the white state function
def handle_white_state():
    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B
    sleep(50)
    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)
    sleep(50)
    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)
    sleep(50)
    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)
    if pin7.read_digital():
        state = IDLE
        sleep(500)

# Main state machine
while True:
    if state == IDLE:
        handle_idle_state()
    elif state == RED:
        handle_red_state()
    elif state == GREEN:
        handle_green_state()
    elif state == BLUE:
        handle_blue_state()
    elif state == WHITE:
        handle_white_state()

sequences between Dark, Red, Green, \n# Blue and mixed colors\n# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness\n# of each color\n# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive\n# Pin 4 to Pot\n# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware\n\nfrom microbit import *\n\ndisplay.off()\n\n# Defining the state identiification\nIDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)\n# Initializing the states\nstate = IDLE\n\n# Defining the idle state function\ndef handle_idle_state():\n    global state\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = RED\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the red state function\ndef handle_red_state():\n    global state, angle_R\n    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = GREEN\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the green state function\ndef handle_green_state():\n    global state, angle_G\n    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = BLUE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the blue state function\ndef handle_blue_state():\n    global state, angle_B\n    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = WHITE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the white state function\ndef handle_white_state():\n    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = IDLE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Main state machine\nwhile True:\n    if state == IDLE:\n        handle_idle_state()\n    elif state == RED:\n        handle_red_state()\n    elif state == GREEN:\n        handle_green_state()\n    elif state == BLUE:\n        handle_blue_state()\n    elif state == WHITE:\n        handle_white_state()\n\n\n\n'

2020-03-22 17:56:22,609 - mu.modes.microbit:250(flash) DEBUG: b'# Write your code here :-)\n# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan\n# ECE 210 Lab 6\n# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, \n# Blue and mixed colors\n# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness\n# of each color\n# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive\n# Pin 4 to Pot\n# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware\n\nfrom microbit import *\n\ndisplay.off()\n\n# Defining the state identiification\nIDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)\n# Initializing the states\nstate = IDLE\n\n# Defining the idle state function\ndef handle_idle_state():\n    global state\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = RED\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the red state function\ndef handle_red_state():\n    global state, angle_R\n    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = GREEN\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the green state function\ndef handle_green_state():\n    global state, angle_G\n    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = BLUE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the blue state function\ndef handle_blue_state():\n    global state, angle_B\n    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = WHITE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the white state function\ndef handle_white_state():\n    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = IDLE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Main state machine\nwhile True:\n    if state == IDLE:\n        handle_idle_state()\n    elif state == RED:\n        handle_red_state()\n    elif state == GREEN:\n        handle_green_state()\n    elif state == BLUE:\n        handle_blue_state()\n    elif state == WHITE:\n        handle_white_state()\n\n\n\n'

2020-03-22 17:59:22,121 - mu.modes.microbit:249(flash) DEBUG: Python script:
2020-03-22 17:59:22,121 - mu.modes.microbit:250(flash) DEBUG: b'# Write your code here :-)\n# This program was written by Giri Venkataramanan\n# ECE 210 Lab 6\n# When you press the PB, the RGB LED sequences between Dark, Red, Green, \n# Blue and mixed colors\n# During the colored states, the POT can be used to set the brightness\n# of each color\n# Pins 1-2-3 are to RGB of common cathode LED drive\n# Pin 4 to Pot\n# Pin 7 to reading the push-button switch with debounced hardware\n\nfrom microbit import *\n\ndisplay.off()\n\n# Defining the state identiification\nIDLE, RED, GREEN, BLUE, WHITE = range(5)\n# Initializing the states\nstate = IDLE\n\n# Defining the idle state function\ndef handle_idle_state():\n    global state\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = RED\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the red state function\ndef handle_red_state():\n    global state, angle_R\n    angle_R = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = GREEN\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the green state function\ndef handle_green_state():\n    global state, angle_G\n    angle_G = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin3.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = BLUE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the blue state function\ndef handle_blue_state():\n    global state, angle_B\n    angle_B = pin4.read_analog()\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    pin1.write_analog(0)\n    pin2.write_analog(0)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = WHITE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Defining the white state function\ndef handle_white_state():\n    global state, angle_R, angle_G, angle_B\n    sleep(50)\n    pin1.write_analog(angle_R)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin2.write_analog(angle_G)\n    sleep(50)\n    pin3.write_analog(angle_B)\n    if pin7.read_digital():\n        state = IDLE\n        sleep(500)\n\n# Main state machine\nwhile True:\n    if state == IDLE:\n        handle_idle_state()\n    elif state == RED:\n        handle_red_state()\n    elif state == GREEN:\n        handle_green_state()\n    elif state == BLUE:\n        handle_blue_state()\n    elif state == WHITE:\n        handle_white_state()\n\n\n\n'

title: Flask server not shut down on quit
body:
* What you were trying to do?
Quit Mu. :)

* What steps you took to make this happen:
Start the simple example "Hello, Mu" Flask example, verify that it loads in the browser. It does. Quit Mu. Refresh browser on Hello, Mu page. Start a Flask web site up from another IDE (VS Code).

* What you expected to happen:
I expected the server to respond with the site launched by VS Code

* What actually happened:
First I got a 404, then on paring the URL down to http://localhost:5000/, I got the Hello Mu page. So it looks like the Flask process kicked off by Mu is still running even though Mu is not.

* Why this difference is problematic (it may not be a bug!):
Normally I'd expect a process started within my IDE to get killed when the IDE quits.

* Technical details like the version of Mu you're using, your OS version and
  other aspects of the context in which Mu was running. 
Running Windows 10 with Mu 1.1.0.alpha.2

Please remember to attach a **copy of the full log files for Mu**.
```

may macOS Chinese lang not support by mu

title: Debugging windows don't retain formatting changes
body:
Hi! New to Mu! New to programming. Just started using the "Debugger" in Python 3 mode. When the debugger stops at a breakpoint, the "Names" and "Values" pane opens up to the right. So far so good. But, I like to resize the "Names" and "Values" column (so there's more space between the two), and expand any expandable items (like a dictionary, for instance), so that I can see everything quickly and clearly at a glance. However, when I click on the "Step Over" button to execute the next line of code, my reformatting goes away. The columns are now scrunched up again, and any expanded items get collapsed. So I end up reformatting that window each time I step through my code.
Is there a way to retain my formatting choices while stepping through my code?
Windows 10, btw, if that makes a difference.

title: make.py vs. make | Inconsistent behaviour
body:
While exploring #941, I checked out the [`use-venv`](https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/tree/use-venv) branch on both Windows and macOS.

Then, essentially, ran `make win64` on the Windows system, and `make macos` on macOS. The Windows build progressed and built a Windows Mu installer. Interestingly, the macOS make stopped because `flake8` did not pass. Here's a snippet:
```
flake8
./mu/interface/dialogs.py:19:1: F401 'os' imported but unused
./mu/interface/dialogs.py:20:1: F401 'sys' imported but unused
./mu/interface/dialogs.py:22:1: F401 'csv' imported but unused
./mu/interface/dialogs.py:23:1: F401 'shutil' imported but unused
./mu/interface/panes.py:20:1: F401 'site' imported but unused
./mu/modes/python3.py:22:1: F401 'mu.logic.VENV_DIR' imported but unused
./mu/modes/python3.py:22:1: F401 'mu.logic.VENV_PYTHON' imported but unused
make: *** [flake8] Error 1
```

Why this happens: both "make targets" include a dependency on `check` which, among other things, runs `flake8`. On macOS, running `make`, `flake8` returns a non-successful status and `make` aborts. On Windows something is going on, because `flake8` complained about the same exact things, but the `win64` target did not abort.

Looks like an easy fix.

PS: Just wanted to log this here. Back to helping out with #941. :)

title: macOS | Crash when "clicking-away" a REPL tooltip
body:
## The horrible crash

* What you were trying to do,

  * Open REPL.
  * Type some code and a tool tip shows up at some point.
  * Click somewhere outside of the tool tip, but within the REPL, to "close away" the tooltip.

* What steps you took to make this happen,

  * Open REPL.
  * Type in "import sys, subprocess"
  * Type in "subprocess.run(".
  * At this point, a very large tooltip is displayed.
  * Use the mouse cursor to click outside the tool tip, but within the REPL pane.

* What you expected to happen,

  * The tool tip to close.

* What actually happened,

  * Mu crashed.
  * Launched from the command line a stack trace is printed:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/tiago.montes/Work/Python/github.com/mu/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/qtconsole/call_tip_widget.py", line 89, in hideEvent
    self._cursor_position_changed)
TypeError: 'method' object is not connected
```

* Technical details like the version of Mu you're using, your OS version and
  other aspects of the context in which Mu was running. 

  * Mu 1.1.0a2, commit b341cec, launched from command line under development venv.
  * The packaged 1.1.0a2 version at https://codewith.mu/en/download behaves the same.
  * Running macOS 10.12.6.

## Parting words

* Came here in a hurry just to have it logged.
* Does not fail on Windows.
* Did not try on Linux.
* A kind of similar failure can be seen [here](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/issues/10050), where updating `qtconsole` seems to have solved it.
* We might need to address #893, thus.

title: Webmode hard crash when another server is listening on localhost:5000
body:
I have a Flask app running on localhost:5000, which is totally unrelated to Mu. When I start Mu and create a further Flask app in its web mode and hit "Run", an `OSError` is raised stating that the address is already in use. When I click on "Stop" Mu crashes.

### Steps
- Flask app listening on localhost:5000
- Start further app in Mu web mode
- OSError
- Mu crahses

>  * Debug mode: on

title: EP2019 BD | Webmode fails when file saved elsewhere
body:
### Observed behaviour

* Jinja2 exception rendered in the browser.

### Expected behaviour

* The "hello" page should be displayed in the browser.


### Steps to reproduce

* Start Mu.
* Change to web mode.
* Create a new file and immediately save it under, say, `~/Desktop`.
* Click the Run button.
* Click the Browser button.

A ** jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound** page is displayed.

### Notes

Verified both on macOS and Windows 10, running from source.


PS: Might be related to a very odd behaviour we observed with André at the Beginner's Day. I have asked him to run a few tests to help out diagnose his particular case and invited him to join the discussion here.

title: EP2019 BD | Webmode hard crash on macOS
body:
### Context

* Observed during EP2019 Beginners' Day sessions.
* User running macOS 10.14.x with UI set to German.
* Mu 1.1.0.alpha2 (probably commit 4678e35c309849f6ec0e14422af34e00ba362e81) installed from the DMG image distributed at https://codewith.mu.

### Behaviour

* Mu launched by double clicking its icon in the Finder.
* Mu set to web mode.
* The it either crashed when (sorry, can't remember fully):
  * Starting the web server.
  * Having it respond to the first request (inclined to believe this was the actual case).

### More info

* I have collected the full log which Michael (the user) was kind enough to email me.
* Won't paste it in full here, because of its size (but keeping it, in case anyone wants to dig deeper).
* A few suspect lines show up repeatedly:

```
2019-07-09 11:04:33,196 - mu.modes.web:182(stop_server) DEBUG: Stopping Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:04:33,196 - root:96(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 122, in run_toggle
self.stop_server()
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 186, in stop_server
os.kill(pid, signal.SIGINT)
KeyboardInterrupt
2019-07-09 11:04:37,056 - root:113(run) INFO:
...
2019-07-09 11:05:16,080 - mu.modes.web:175(start_server) DEBUG: Starting Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:05:52,312 - mu.modes.web:182(stop_server) DEBUG: Stopping Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:05:52,312 - root:96(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 122, in run_toggle
self.stop_server()
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 186, in stop_server
os.kill(pid, signal.SIGINT)
KeyboardInterrupt
2019-07-09 11:05:56,421 - root:113(run) INFO:
...
2019-07-09 11:06:25,540 - mu.modes.web:175(start_server) DEBUG: Starting Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:06:37,240 - mu.modes.web:182(stop_server) DEBUG: Stopping Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:06:37,240 - root:96(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 122, in run_toggle
self.stop_server()
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 186, in stop_server
os.kill(pid, signal.SIGINT)
KeyboardInterrupt
2019-07-09 11:06:47,712 - root:113(run) INFO:
...
2019-07-09 11:07:33,636 - mu.modes.web:175(start_server) DEBUG: Starting Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:08:15,523 - mu.modes.web:182(stop_server) DEBUG: Stopping Flask app.
2019-07-09 11:08:15,527 - root:96(excepthook) ERROR: Unrecoverable error
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 122, in run_toggle
self.stop_server()
File "/Applications/mu-editor.app/Contents/Resources/app/mu/modes/web.py", line 186, in stop_server
os.kill(pid, signal.SIGINT)
KeyboardInterrupt
2019-07-09 11:09:02,824 - root:113(run) INFO:
```

I'm not familiar with the code, and haven't looked at it but find it interesting that the apparent crash (at least we get no more entries after these lines other than the first message Mu logs when starting up) is after an `os.kill(pid, ...)`: is Mu committing suicide? :)

### More

* I tried playing around with my system's configuration, including changing UI languages, building a "packaged macOS app", running "from source", etc., but completely failed to reproduce the crash.
* I'll try to see if Michael has a github user account and if we wants to follow up on the issue and help us identify the underlying cause.

title: Mu copies junk to device on startup

labels.name: devices
labels.description: Requests for new device addition or support for existing devices

body:
If my device is connected when I start Mu, it automatically and without prompting creates a number of directories and copies assets I don't want, apparently for a board I'm not using, to my device.  These include `fonts/`, `images/`, `music/`, and `sounds/`.

It seems I hadn't updated Mu in quite some time, as the offending code has been in there for about a year: https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/blob/3393a2ca7ee793df6a2c9d655ca926dd86074e4a/mu/logic.py#L626

* On any of these devices 50-60KB of unnecessary assets is an awful lot, on my Trinket M0 based project it exhausts "disk" space
* If there isn't sufficient space on the device, Mu crashes on launch (#873)
* I'm not using a pygamezero, why is code for that running on every startup of Mu anyway?
* _Always **always** ask before copying things to the user's board_

I'm running Mu 1.0.2 on macOS Mojave 10.14.5 (18F132) and have confirmed the problem with Adafruit Trinket M0, ItsyBitsy M0, and ItsyBitsy M4; log is pasted below.

# Mu log:

title: Cannot start mu-portable 1.02 32 on win 10
body:
I have only problems ;-( What a life...
I want to help my friend who teach in one school and don't have access to administration of Windows, so cannot install any soft.
I think - ok, lets try mu-portable copied to student's Desktop directory . So I downloaded it and test in my clean fresh win 10 in Virtualbox.
![VirtualBox_Windows 10_07_06_2019_13_20_01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5088643/59101164-70762980-8928-11e9-9046-17a32c41074c.png)

Error! The same, as it was when I had Python 3.7 and tried to run mu installed standard way. 
But, now I have 3.6 and normal mu-editor works....

title: Mu should handle unknown files when checking for duplicates.
body:
```

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Program Files (x86)\Mu\pkgs\mu\logic.py", line 831, in load
    self._load(path)
  File "C:\Program Files (x86)\Mu\pkgs\mu\logic.py", line 730, in _load
    if os.path.samefile(path, widget.path):
  File "genericpath.py", line 97, in samefile
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 3] The system cannot find the path specified: 'D:/main.py'
```

Mu had a file open from a subsequently unplugged CircuitPlaygroundExpress (i.e. the file was no longer accessible).

title: Installing on Windows raises a PermissionError against the registry
body:
This is a placeholder issue until I can reproduce it but, from memory:

Win10 Pro 17134
64-bit 1.0.1 installer from codewith.mu 
Installed with default settings
During the installation messages I noticed a PermissionError exception relating to a registry key.

At the time I was with a bunch of Year 8s and was moving fairly quickly so I didn't pick up the message. I'll look for NSIS logs and/or reproduce. There were no apparent problem actually running Mu afterwards, although we were only doing very simple things

MU is showing the name of the REPL as Python3 (Jupiter) REPL. The message in the REPL windows are "Kernel died, Restarting".

I have Python 3.7.0 installed on my machine, both `ipython` and `python3` commands open a Python 3.7 REPL. The 'python' command runs the Apple installed  Python 2.7.5 REPL.

title: Mu Python Mode Using System Python not Virtual Environment on Linux
body:
I've managed to get Mu working on Mint (18.2) with Python 3.7, in a virtual environment, but when I switch to standard Python Mode and open up the REPL it shows Python 3.5.2 as the version number (the default Python 3 interpreter for the version of Mint I'm on).

If I want to do Pygame stuff directly in the Python editor, that'll mean that I need to ensure Pygame is installed on 3.5.2 outside the virtual environment.

Dave

title: Debugger breakpoint markers cannot be removed
body:
When a debugger marker is placed on the marging and then the text is modified, the marker moves with the changes. When this happens then it's not possible to remove the markers anymore.

Gif showing the issue:

![mu breakpoints](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4189262/38678204-4cb239e2-3e58-11e8-97d6-d224f1114369.gif)

title: Removing a breakpoint in the debugger causes an exception
body:
Might be related to issue https://github.com/mu-editor/mu/issues/403 - Adding a breakpoint in the debugger causes an exception.

This happened in beta 15 on a Raspberry Pi (the one that apt-get currently installs). I was adding a breakpoint and the application closed when I clicked on it again to remove it.

The log is quite large as I was doing a lot of different stuff in Mu for quite a while, and it also contains bits that can't really be shared publicly (API keys), so I'll copy the relevant part here:
```
2018-04-07 13:08:56,968 - mu.modes.python3:183(debug) INFO: Starting debug mode.
2018-04-07 13:08:57,059 - mu.logic:712(change_mode) INFO: Workspace directory: /home/pi/mu_code
2018-04-07 13:08:57,060 - mu.modes.debugger:112(start) DEBUG: from twython import TwythonStreamer
from sense_hat import SenseHat
from colorzero import Color
from auth import (
    consumer_key,
    consumer_secret,
    access_token,
    access_token_secret
)

sense = SenseHat()
hashtag = '#cheerlights'

class MyStreamer(TwythonStreamer):
    def on_success(self, data):
        if 'text' in data:
            tweet = data['text']
            tweet = tweet.replace(hashtag, '')
            color_text = tweet.strip()
            try:
                color = Color(color_text)
                sense.clear(color.rgb_bytes)
            except ValueError:
                print('Failed: {}'.format(color_text))
stream = MyStreamer(
    consumer_key,
    consumer_secret,
    access_token,
    access_token_secret
)
stream.statuses.filter(track=hashtag)

title: Specifying a file on the command-line can duplicate if it's also in the restored session
body: If you specify a file on the command line (eg mu myfile.py) and that file is also stored in the session settings, it will be loaded twice.

title: Adding a breakpoint in the debugger causes an exception

title: Automatically saved encoding cookie messes with lines listed in REPL
body: Edit: Changed "shebang" for "encoding cookie" for clarification of what I meant. *** Because of the encoding cookie is added to the file but not shown on the editor the lines displayed and executed are different. In this simple example you can see line 4 in the editor is reported as line 5 in the "run" error.

title: Debugger - stepping over the final line of code results in an IndexError exception
body:
When using the debugger, if you step over the final line of code in any program it results in:

```
exception: IndexError('list index out of range',)1
```

... and the program restarts from the break point. If you then step over the program again, it completes with no errors.

![ezgif com-optimize 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2329501/36378135-8b6dd55c-1571-11e8-8b5e-633a907d0cdc.gif)

title: Debugger, breakpoints on line 1 point break
body:
If you place a break point on line 1 of programmer the debugger doesn't stop at the breakpoint. 

A breakpoint on line 2 works fine.

To replicate, set a breakpoint on line 1 of a program and click **debug**  - it should stop at line 1, but it doesn't.

![ezgif com-optimize 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2329501/36377545-7b2a154a-156f-11e8-9e18-cce6a3a4393f.gif)

title: Debugger, runs to completion if there are no breakpoints
body:
Im not sure if this is by design or a bug.

If you have no breakpoints in your program and you click **Debug**, Mu runs the program to completion, from a users perspective it is the same as clicking **Run**. 

The debugger only stops execution of the code and allows it to be debugged if you have placed a break point in your program.

This creates a little friction for the new user, as they have to know how to create a break point before they can debug their code.

As an alternative - when the debugger starts, could it break point on the first line allowing the user to run to the next breakpoint, step through, etc.

title: Pygame Zero mode doesn't finish running when the program finishes
body:
Switch to Pygame Zero mode
Run some code (even an empty file)
Let it finish (eg Ctrl-Q or your game dies or whatever)

mu is still in "Running" mode and won't offer the "Play" button until the "Stop" button is pressed

title: Need to check for file permission before attempting to save.
body:
If we open a file that is read only for the user and try to save we don't safeguard for `PermissionError`:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\workspace\git\microbit\mu_original\mu\logic.py", line 601, in save
    with open(tab.path, 'w', newline='') as f:
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'C:/Users/xxx/mu_code/test_locked.py'
```
We should catch this, and then either:
a) Ask the user to manually remove the permission and try again
b) Ask if the user wants Mu to change the read permission and continue saving
